source.author: Jeanes, J.A.
source.title: Haloragaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: From: Jeanes, J.A. (1996). Haloragaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Leaves opposite, at least on lower stems, linear to ovate, neither terete nor divided (but often serrate)
Leaves alternate, rarely opposite on lower stems and, if so, trifid or terete
Large riparian shrub; leaves mostly 60–100 mm long
Herb or subshrub; leaves less than 60 mm long
[link through]
Leaves narrow-ovate to ovate, toothed, coriaceous; fruit becoming 3-celled by abortion; rare plant from the Portland region
Leaves linear, entire, trifid or pinnatifid, somewhat fleshy; fruit 4-celled
Leaves with distinct petiole to 20 mm long; fruit usually prominently winged; far north-west only
Leaves sessile or very shortly petiolate; fruit not prominently winged (winged in H. acutangula)
Leaves narrow-lanceolate to narrow-ovate, serrate at least in distal part
Leaves terete or trifid
Plant scabrous
Plant smooth or ribbed; rare plant of the north-west
Stem hairs hooked at the tip, 2–4-celled; leaves subglaucous
Stem hairs curved, 1- or 2-celled; leaves glaucous; rare plant of the north-west
Fruiting sepals linear, less than 0.6 mm wide; bracteoles less than 1 mm long; leaves glaucous
Fruiting sepals deltoid, more than 0.7 mm wide; bracteoles more than 1 mm long; leaves green
[link through]
Fruiting sepals linear, less than 0.6 mm wide; bracteoles less than 1 mm long; leaves glaucous
Fruiting sepals deltoid, more than 0.7 mm wide; bracteoles more than 1 mm long; leaves green
[link through]
Leaves terete, sometimes sparsely lobed or tuberculately toothed
Leaves trifid, at least toward base, often entire and narrow-elliptic toward the inflorescence
